text: 8. He made no mention of a staged rescue. That was his version. It seems of public interest in light of the new details in the story.
author: mattaikins

text: 7. The town was held by rebels. He was fed and cared for, and eventually they took him across the border to safety in Turkey.
author: mattaikins

text: 6. After another night in the fields, he reached a town and, desperate, approached the locals and announced that he had been kidnapped.
author: mattaikins

text: 5. He hid out for the rest of the night and subsequent day, and the following night, walked shoeless in the direction he guessed was north.
author: mattaikins

text: 4. He waited at a distance in the darkness to see if others would escape as well, but eventually the van drove away, leaving him alone.
author: mattaikins

text: 3. He said when their van was stopped at night in the "rescue", he leaped out during the gunfire and ran into the night, still bound.

text: 9. ... focusing on one small, highly-classified program can obscure the way that torture and abuse were much wider practices in these wars.
author: mattaikins

text: 8. The CIA torture program is a historic crime, and the report and debate around highly important, but...
author: mattaikins

text: 7. The military justice system has an abysmal record of accountability, as this recent @amnesty report shows so well.
author: mattaikins

text: 6. Unlike the CIA, torture and abuse were never part of authorized US military policy, but it's fair to say they were recurring and systemic
author: mattaikins

text: 5. On Iraq, read @joshesphillips excellent, nuanced book on soldiers who were involved in torture and abuse. http://noneofuswerelikethisbefore.com/
author: mattaikins

text: 4. Torture by our allies is widespread. Here's a video I found of American soldiers watching a detainee whipped.
author: mattaikins

text: 3. @Anand_Gopal_'s new book also contains extensive accounts of abuse and torture by US forces in Afghanistan, going back to 2001.
author: mattaikins

text: 2. Allegations of abuse, including genital-twisting and physical beatings, were in my piece on an SF team last year.
author: mattaikins

text: 1. Torture was not just done by the CIA. There is a pattern of abuse during interrogations by the US military in Iraq and Afghanistan, too.
author: mattaikins

text: 13. and not blind you to it out of revulsion to the barbarism of a few.
author: mattaikins

text: 12. Let Steven and James’ deaths expand your moral imagination, bring you in solidarity with the suffering people of the Middle East
author: mattaikins

text: 11. of suffering that goes on daily in these places. If our deaths obscure that, then we’ve failed in a final way.
author: mattaikins

text: 10. What always animated me most of all was that the sense of my possible suffering, even my family’s suffering, was but a drop in an ocean
author: mattaikins

text: 9. why journos like Sotloff, and others-including myself-risked their lives to go to Syria. We wanted to make their suffering real to you.
author: mattaikins

text: 8. We should all mourn Sotloff, and other Westerners, but in a way that brings us in solidarity with all victims of the war, lest we forget…
author: mattaikins

text: 7. Her point (post-9/11) is that mourning can serve as a kind of exclusion, heightening our sense of precariousness and limiting empathy.
author: mattaikins

text: 6. Butler also says that “I am as much constituted by those I do grieve for as by those whose deaths I avow.”
author: mattaikins

text: 5. This refers to “public” mourning. Of course you can’t compare different loved ones’ grief. But virtually none of the public knew Sotloff.
author: mattaikins

text: 4. Simply compare the 9/11 memorial, and the Iraq Body Count project, for a sense of how differently lives are memorialized and mourned.
author: mattaikins

text: 3. Her point: certain lives are grieved differently, in a way related to the distribution of power and the representation of violence.
author: mattaikins

text: 2. Butler reminds us that “the obituary functions as an instrument by which grievability is publicly distributed.”
author: mattaikins

text: 1. On this sad occasion, some thoughts on grief in the news, as opposed to personal, context, inspired by Butler’s “Precarious Life.”

text: I wrote a little Twitter essay on the role crap media coverage played in the current Afghan election debacle.
author: mattaikins

text: 15. Greater scrutiny of the 1st round might have prevented this. What kind of patriotism is it to abdicate your responsibility to the truth?
author: mattaikins

text: 14. Because the IEC and ECC failed, there is no objective way forward. It will be resolved politically, in a way that disenfranchises voters
author: mattaikins

text: 13. If there is one thing that previous elections have shown, it’s that you can’t legitimize results after the fact. Work needs to be before
author: mattaikins

text: 12. So we don’t know how clean the first round was. No one checked and no one challenged. And that set the stage for the current disaster.
author: mattaikins

text: 11. But ECC completely failed. IEC did well logistically but almost no independent check on fraud. See: http://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/elections-2014-19-final-results-timeline-trumps-transparency …
author: mattaikins

text: 10. Afghan elites were happy with good’ story. Ghani and Abdullah happy to move to 2nd round. So everything was swept under the carpet.
author: mattaikins

text: 9. Performance of local media was even more distressing. Widespread censorship in the name of “patriotism.” http://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/elections-2014-17-journalists-argue-over-neutrality-patriotism-and-the-e-day-blackout …
author: mattaikins

text: 8. Not to pick on the NYT but this “Afghan vote a success” piece gives good example of “peaceful” and “fair” angle
author: mattaikins

text: 7. Also narrative of “peaceful” election day. Maybe in cities, but overall violence higher than in 2009.
author: mattaikins

text: 6. There are other examples, but most foreign journos didn’t leave Kabul or main cities-yet 75% of the population is rural.
author: mattaikins

text: 5. Turnout and violence was low in the cities, but those who visited rural areas saw a different story, e.g.
author: mattaikins

text: 4. Another colleague, writing for @AANAfgh, found 2/3 of Andar’s centers never opened. Again, mostly included. http://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/elections-2014-14-why-two-thirds-of-andars-polling-centres-may-have-never-opened …
author: mattaikins

text: 3. E.g. Anand_Gopal_ and I witnessed a ghost polling station in Wardak, whose results were included in final tally.
author: mattaikins

text: 2. First round was marked by both fair celebration at turnout and unjustifiable, willful blindness to serious irregularities and fraud.
author: mattaikins

text: 16. Congratulations to the Afghan people, if not their corrupt politicians. Strong oversight and pressure is needed now to ensure fair count
author: mattaikins

text: 15. Maybe I’m just an incorrigible critic. Enjoy the party, the hangover will be there tomorrow: weeks of counting and tangled adjudication.
author: mattaikins

text: 14. I don’t see how ignoring fraud honors the millions of voters who did turn out, but prevailing narrative seems to be blind celebration.
author: mattaikins

text: 13. Is voting in Wardak so different from Ghazni? From Urozgan? From Loya Paktia? No one knows because no one goes.
author: mattaikins

text: 12. In 2010 in Wardak, 399 polling stations were planned, all but ten opened despite insecurity, 37.4% later disqualified due to fraud.
author: mattaikins

text: 11. My general impression was that the voting in Wardak was marked by very low turnout and significant fraud—like in 2009 and 2010.
author: mattaikins

text: 10. Many centers had been opened in insecure areas that could not be monitored properly. We were told many co-opted by local ALP strongmen.
author: mattaikins

text: 9. Turnout was very low in centers along Highway 1, except in provincial capital and Dasht-e Towp. Some places had 30-40 votes all day.
author: mattaikins

text: 8. Strong, organized Afghan security forces on highway also helped, especially ALP militias. But they have a downside, which I’ll get to.
author: mattaikins

text: 7. Taliban limited themselves to potshots, but ran a widespread night letter and threat campaign cited by locals as reason for low turnout.
author: mattaikins

text: 6. Relatively low violence-which I had predicted, based on fact that Taliban had not been pressuring provincial campaigns in run-up.
author: mattaikins

text: 5. Wardak is a rough place. High levels of violence, strong insurgency, malign contractor barons, petri dish for US militia experiments.
author: mattaikins

text: 4. Divide is obscured by fact that Western press, diplomats and NGOs increasingly limited to cities. That’s why we went to war-torn Wardak.
author: mattaikins

text: 3. Critical fact about Afghanistan is growing divide between rural and urban, on security, development, and much else—-including elections.
author: mattaikins

text: 2. Afghans are deservedly euphoric about democratic gains and apparently high turnout. My way of honoring them is to do my job as a critic.
author: mattaikins

text: 1. Some impressions on the Afghan presidential election from observing the vote in Wardak Province today with @Anand_Gopal_ and @muzhary
author: mattaikins

text: In 2009 it took 27 days for preliminary final results to be announced, in 2010, over a month. Patience.
author: mattaikins

text: @_EmmaGH Preliminary vote count was 5.6 million. 4.6 million was final total after IEC and ECC disqualifications.

text: A lot of wet cops and soldiers lining the roads from Wardak to Kabul.
author: mattaikins

text: Hundreds of cars stuck at Kabul-Wardak border. Impressed by cops: shouted at by bigwigs, only allowing journalists and election workers.
author: mattaikins

text: Yep, it's a rainbow over the happy magic valley of Sayedabad. No unicorns yet.
author: mattaikins

text: Lots of night letters and threats from Taliban cited by Wardakis as reasons not to vote. But little actual attacks today.

text: 38 votes cast in a Wardak polling center.  Number 39? Our very own @Muzhary.

text: So far our general impression in Wardak is very low turnout in the polling stations on Highway 1, with exception of Dasht-e Towp and Maidan.
